message_1: A museum has a collection of 20 paintings, but only has space to display 5 at a time. In how many ways can the museum choose which paintings to display if each painting must be displayed exactly once?
message_2:
To determine the number of ways the museum can choose which paintings to display, we can use the combination formula, which is:

C(n, k) = n! / (k!(n-k)!)

where n is the total number of paintings (20) and k is the number of paintings to be displayed at a time (5).

C(20, 5) = 20! / (5!(20-5)!)

C(20, 5) = 20! / (5!15!)

C(20, 5) = (20*19*18*17*16) / (5*4*3*2*1)

C(20, 5) = 15504

So, there are 15,504 different ways the museum can choose which paintings to display if each painting must be displayed exactly once.
